Explanation:Â There it goes. That small spot moving in front of background stars in theÂ above videoÂ is a potentially dangerous asteroid passing above the Earthâs atmosphere. This past Friday, the 50-meter wide asteroidÂ 2012 DA14Â just missed the Earth,Â passingÂ not only inside the orbit of the Moon, which isÂ unusually closeÂ for an asteroid of this size, but also inside the orbit ofÂ geosynchronous satellites. Unfortunately, asteroids this big orÂ biggerÂ strike the EarthÂ every 1000 yearsÂ or so. Were2012 DA14Â to have hit the Earth, it could have devastated aÂ city-sized landscape, or stuck an ocean and raisedÂ dangerous tsunamis. Although finding and tracking potentially dangerous asteroids is a primary concern of modern astronomy, these small bodies or ice and rock are typically so dim that only aÂ few percent of themÂ have been found, so far. Even smaller chunks of ice and rock, like the (unrelated) spectacular meteors thatÂ streaked over RussiaÂ andÂ CaliforniaÂ over the past few days, are even harder to find â but pose less danger.
